component.text: Roll over the ACL fields to view descriptions and options.
Identifies an ACL with a unique number. A standard ACL uses numbers in the ranges 1 - 99 and 1300 to 1999. Extended ACLs use numbers in the ranges 100 - 199 and 2000 - 2699.
Identifies whether a packet is to be permitted or denied.

Identifies Layer 3 / 4 protocols. Common options include:
eigrp Cisco's EIGRP routing protocol
esp Encapsulation Security Payload
gre Cisco's GRE tunneling
icmp Internet Control Message Protocol
igmp Internet Gateway Message Protocol
ip Any Internet Protocol
ipinip IP in IP tunneling
ospf OSPF routing protocol
pcp Payload Compression Protocol
tcp Transmission Control Protocol
udp User Datagram Protocol

Identifies the IP address of the source of the packet. This value can be:
  • An individual host address
  • A range of host addresses
  • The host parameter
  • The any parameter

Identifies the IP address of the destination of the packets. This value can be:
  • An Individual host address
  • A range of host addresses
  • The host parameter
  • The any parameter
Determines whether certain fields must match the application equally, greater than, less than and so on.
Identifies the application either by port number or acronym.
